stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses almost the entire session on polishing the new Bowser-themed construction/oil-rig course: adjusting crane colours, fixing a mis-UV’d floor switch, hunting a coin-related rendering bug, optimising N64 performance, and—above all—designing an ‘infinite’ ocean backdrop that feels vast yet runs on hardware.
level: Bowser protest / oil-rig stage (internally still course 11 – Wet-Dry World slot)

development_findings.summary: Current task is adding coins, recolouring cranes, and designing an ocean/fog background for the Bowser protest level so it feels less ‘dead’.
Kaze discovered the whole level had been exported with F3D microcode instead of F3DEX2, doubling vertex load and command count; re-exporting gains significant FPS headroom.
development_findings.quote: Funniest thing ever: we were exporting as an F3D model, not F3DEX2, so we had twice the vertex loads and it still ran fine.

development_findings.summary: Target worst-case performance is ~22 FPS on real N64 before back-face culling, render-area splits, triangle sorting, and link-time optimisations that Kaze expects will add 5–6 FPS.
development_findings.quote: Whatever you're seeing right now is probably going to be 5-6 slower than what actually is going to be in the final game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze will enable back-face culling on gates and sort triangles; collision map is still unoptimised, all to reduce lag in the densest spots.
Directional/world lighting is only possible because they integrated Wiseguy’s ‘Matrix Stack Fix’.
development_findings.quote: Use Wiseguy's Matrix Stack Fix … then you just put a light and it will be a world light.

development_findings.summary: A coin formation near a crane caused memory corruption and missing geometry; removing or relocating the formation fixed the render bug.
Experimented with nfbg vs 3-D water; concluded an actual curved water mesh with a gradient linked to camera movement best sells an endless ocean without breaking culling limits.
development_findings.quote: I think the NBG is just not possible here … the ocean has to be in the 3-D model.

development_findings.summary: Newly updated NEMU64 (2023) is now Kaze’s preferred emulator because it offers live GDB debugging and cache emulation.
development_findings.quote: A new emulator dropped called NEMU64 … you can debug everything with it.

development_findings.summary: Merch possibility: custom company offered to print authentic-looking N64 boxes + manuals; Kaze considers selling boxes alone (legal) and separate OST ROM, even ‘hiring people’ if it works.
development_findings.quote: Dude, when I sell RTYI, I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal … maybe I'm gonna start hiring people.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works full-time as a C/C++ programmer; development streams happen in spare time.
context_findings.quote: I have a full-time job on the side, so that's why I don't have too much time to just work on this all the time.

context_findings.summary: He jokes about monetising Twitter (5 M impressions) and believes Twitch will ‘die’, hence streaming on YouTube.
context_findings.quote: We're gonna activate the demonetization on Twitter … and I'm never gonna pay for Twitter Blue again.

context_findings.summary: Expresses ambition to form a ‘full ROM-making company’ if merch revenue is viable.
Shows light frustration with chat but also pride in community intelligence; self-deprecates about being a ‘vampire’ indoors coder.
context_findings.quote: Why are people in my chat so smart compared to the average person on the planet? I think everyone here just gets smarter by watching me.

biobak.summary: Delivered an improved purple floor-switch model (1 336 polys vs 4 000+) fitting in a tiny texture; Kaze integrates it immediately.
biobak.quote: This is so much better than the one we had before—actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

biobak.summary: Suggested colour-coding cranes and adding a blue-to-purple horizon gradient; Kaze adopts these ideas while tuning the background.

zeina.summary: Absent this session; Kaze notes she would have finished an animation for a character in the stage.
zeina.quote: Unfortunately Zeina's gone today, otherwise she maybe would have finished the animation for the guy here.

key_stories.title: Export Format Performance Bug
key_stories.summary: The level felt heavier than expected on hardware. While reviewing shading, Kaze noticed the exporter was set to F3D instead of the faster F3DEX2.
key_stories.challenge: Low FPS in a huge Bowser construction level.
key_stories.process: Checked shading flags, then realised the exporter target; rebuilt with correct microcode.
key_stories.outcome: Halved vertex commands; gained several FPS headroom for later effects.
key_stories.key_quote: We were exporting as an F3D model and not F3DEX2, so we had twice the vertex loads and it still ran fine.

key_stories.title: Coin Formation Crash
key_stories.summary: Adding vertical coin strings suddenly blanked large portions of geometry.
key_stories.challenge: Mysterious memory corruption causing Mario and parts of level to vanish.
key_stories.process: Systematically removed recent coin formations; tested; isolated one near the crane hook.
key_stories.outcome: Bug fixed; notes to watch object-table limits.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you recompile the ROM your cheat codes get wiped, so I knew it had to be the new coin formations.

key_stories.title: Infinite Ocean Experiment
key_stories.summary: The stage needed a vast sea but N64 culling prohibits distant geometry.
key_stories.challenge: Make an ‘endless’ oil-slick ocean that doesn’t pop or tank FPS.
key_stories.process: Tried nfbg skybox, fog tricks, then a curved water mesh that moves ~0.9x camera translation plus colour gradient.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on curved mesh; looks convincing and respects hardware limits.
key_stories.key_quote: I think the ocean has to be in the 3-D model; NBG will never work—I can mathematically prove it.

key_stories.title: Switch Model Upgrade
key_stories.summary: Original floor switch UVs were misaligned. Community artist Biobak offered a replacement.
key_stories.process: Tested Nintendo UVs, then imported Biobak’s cleaner model and palette.
key_stories.outcome: Higher-quality, lower-poly switch now standard across Bowser levels.
key_stories.key_quote: Somehow you managed to fit this in such a small texture; this actually just looks like an upgraded version of the Mario 64 one.

key_stories.title: Physical Merch Brainwave
key_stories.summary: A custom printer contacted Kaze about producing N64 boxes.
key_stories.challenge: How to monetise RTYI without infringing Nintendo ROM distribution.
key_stories.process: Realised boxes/manuals alone are legal; considered separate OST ROM; joked about ‘becoming millionaires’.
key_stories.outcome: Exploring costs; would pay contributors if profitable; potential small business.
key_stories.key_quote: I could just sell the box without the ROM, and it'd be legal … maybe I'm gonna start hiring people.

open_questions.context: Stream focuses on visuals but not on why Mario is storming a Bowser construction rig titled ‘protest’.
questions: What is the narrative or thematic purpose of the Bowser protest stage?
How does it fit into RTYI’s overall progression and story?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Zeina would have completed an animation for ‘the guy here’. No details given.
questions: What character is Zeina animating for this level?
What is the workflow between Zeina’s animations and Kaze’s engine integration?

open_questions.context: Kaze hints at enabling a link option that could add 5–6 FPS.
questions: What specific linker or microcode tweaks are planned?
How risky is altering microcode this late in development?

open_questions.context: Kaze praises the updated emulator but gives no specifics on adoption.
questions: How will NEMU64 with GDB change day-to-day debugging?
Any limitations compared with real hardware tests?

open_questions.context: Idea to sell N64 boxes and OST ROMs.
questions: What legal counsel has Kaze consulted regarding selling boxes?
How will revenue be shared among team members like Biobak and Badub?

open_questions.context: Current level still dips to 22 FPS without culling.
questions: What is the minimum acceptable FPS for release?
Will there be optional ‘enhanced’ settings for emulator/PC players?

open_questions.context: Kaze jokes but also seriously mentions paying musicians and hiring.
questions: Has a revenue-sharing model been drafted?
What roles would be prioritised if a ROM-making company forms?
